questions.question_text: A block of mass m1 rests on an incline of angle θ = 20°. The coefficients of static and kinetic friction are μs = 0.8 and μk = 0.5. It is connected via a massless string over a massless and frictionless pulley. Block m2 has mass 2 kg. If m1 = 1.6 kg, what's the magnitude of the acceleration of the m2 (in m/s^2)?
questions.solution:
Solution (expanded, step-by-step following the approach shown in the image):

Step 1 — Identify forces and choose sign conventions
- Let the positive direction be: m2 downward and m1 upward along the incline (this is convenient if m2 tends to pull m1 up the plane).
- Forces on m2: weight $m_2 g$ downward and tension $T$ upward.
- Forces on m1 along the plane: tension $T$ pulling up the plane, the component of gravity $m_1 g\sin\theta$ pulling down the plane, and friction $F_{fr}$ which opposes the tending motion of m1 (if m1 tends to move up the plane friction acts down the plane).
- Normal force on m1: $N = m_1 g\cos\theta$.

Step 2 — Write symbolic equations of motion for each mass
- For m2 (positive downward):
$$m_2 g - T = m_2 a.\tag{1}$$
- For m1 along the plane (positive up the plane):
$$T - m_1 g\sin\theta - F_{fr} = m_1 a.\tag{2}$$
These two equations are the standard pair for two masses connected by a string.

Step 3 — Determine whether the system moves or remains at rest (static friction check)
- The static friction maximum is $F_{s,max}=\mu_s N = \mu_s m_1 g\cos\theta$.
- The force that tends to pull m1 up the plane is due to m2: the effective pull is $m_2 g - m_1 g\sin\theta$ (this is the net driving force before friction is considered).
- If $m_2 g - m_1 g\sin\theta \le F_{s,max}$, the system remains at rest (no acceleration). If greater, motion occurs and kinetic friction applies.

Symbolically:
$$\text{Check: } m_2 g - m_1 g\sin\theta \stackrel{?}{\le} \mu_s m_1 g\cos\theta.$$

Step 4 — Compute the static-friction check numerically (substitute given numbers)
- Given values: $m_2=2.0\ \text{kg}$, $m_1=1.6\ \text{kg}$, $\theta=20^\circ$, $\mu_s=0.8$, $\mu_k=0.5$, $g=9.81\ \text{m/s}^2$.
- Compute the driving term:
$$m_2 g - m_1 g\sin\theta = (2.0)(9.81) - (1.6)(9.81)\sin20^\circ.$$
- Numerically,
  $$(2.0)(9.81)=19.62\ \text{N},$$
  $$(1.6)(9.81)\sin20^\circ \approx 1.6\cdot9.81\cdot0.342020=5.367\ \text{N}.$$
- So the driving term is
$$19.62 - 5.367 = 14.253\ \text{N}.$$
- The maximum static friction is
$$F_{s,max}=\mu_s m_1 g\cos\theta = 0.8\cdot1.6\cdot9.81\cdot\cos20^\circ.$$
- Numerically,
  $\cos20^\circ\approx0.9396926$, so
  $$F_{s,max}\approx 0.8\cdot1.6\cdot9.81\cdot0.9396926 \approx 11.79\ \text{N}.$$
- Compare: $14.253\ \text{N} > 11.79\ \text{N}$, so the driving force exceeds maximum static friction. Therefore the blocks will move; kinetic friction applies.

Step 5 — Express kinetic friction and set up the net equation (symbolic)
- Kinetic friction magnitude:
$$F_{fr}=\mu_k N = \mu_k m_1 g\cos\theta.$$
- Combine equations (1) and (2) to eliminate $T$:
From (1): $T = m_2 g - m_2 a$.
Substitute into (2):
$$(m_2 g - m_2 a) - m_1 g\sin\theta - F_{fr} = m_1 a.$$
Rearrange to solve for $a$:
$$m_2 g - m_1 g\sin\theta - F_{fr} = m_1 a + m_2 a = (m_1 + m_2)a.$$
So symbolically,
$$\boxed{\;a = \dfrac{m_2 g - m_1 g\sin\theta - F_{fr}}{m_1 + m_2}\;}$$
and substitute $F_{fr}=\mu_k m_1 g\cos\theta$ if kinetic friction applies.

Step 6 — Substitute numerical values into the symbolic expression and compute $a$
- Using $F_{fr}=\mu_k m_1 g\cos\theta = 0.5\cdot1.6\cdot9.81\cdot\cos20^\circ$:
  $$F_{fr}\approx 0.5\cdot1.6\cdot9.81\cdot0.9396926 \approx 7.370\ \text{N}.$$
- Now compute the numerator:
  $$m_2 g - m_1 g\sin\theta - F_{fr} \approx 19.62 - 5.367 - 7.370 = 6.883\ \text{N}.$$
- Denominator:
  $$m_1 + m_2 = 1.6 + 2.0 = 3.6\ \text{kg}.$$
- Therefore,
  $$a = \dfrac{6.88255}{3.6} \approx 1.9118\ \text{m/s}^2.$$

Step 7 — State final answer (magnitude)
- The magnitude of the acceleration of $m_2$ is
  $$\boxed{a \approx 1.91\ \text{m/s}^2.}$$

Remarks and checks:
- We first checked static friction to determine whether motion begins. Because the driving force exceeded the maximum static friction, kinetic friction applies and the system accelerates.
- The sign convention chosen (m2 downward positive) gives a positive $a$, confirming that $m_2$ accelerates downward and $m_1$ accelerates up the incline.
- The symbolic formula
  $$a = \dfrac{m_2 g - m_1 g\sin\theta - \mu_k m_1 g\cos\theta}{m_1 + m_2}$$
  is general and can be applied to any similar problem with different numerical values; numerical substitution yields the specific answer above.
